claim: If you wear a hat made out of tin foil, nothing in particular happens.

supporting.text: Tin foil hats do not have any scientifically proven effect on blocking electromagnetic waves or other external influences.

attacks.text: Tin foil hats do not have any scientifically proven effect on blocking electromagnetic waves or other external influences.
Some studies suggest that tin foil can partially block certain frequencies of electromagnetic waves, though not effectively.
The partial blocking observed in studies is negligible in real-world scenarios and does not justify any meaningful effect.
Tin foil hats are often associated with psychological placebo effects, which can make wearers believe something is happening.
Placebo effects are subjective and do not constitute an actual physical or measurable effect of tin foil hats.

supporting.text: Wearing a tin foil hat does not cause any physical harm or health effects under normal circumstances.

attacks.text: Wearing a tin foil hat does not cause any physical harm or health effects under normal circumstances.
Tin foil hats can cause minor skin irritation or discomfort due to prolonged contact with metal.
Skin irritation from tin foil hats is rare and typically only occurs in individuals with metal allergies or sensitive skin.
Tin foil hats may interfere with radio signals, potentially causing minor inconveniences in communication.
The effect of tin foil hats on radio signals is negligible in most real-world scenarios.

supporting.text: There is no empirical evidence that tin foil hats provide protection against mind control or surveillance, as often claimed in conspiracy theories.

attacks.text: There is no empirical evidence that tin foil hats provide protection against mind control or surveillance, as often claimed in conspiracy theories.
Some studies suggest that tin foil can block certain electromagnetic frequencies, which could theoretically interfere with surveillance technologies.
The blocking effect of tin foil is minimal and inconsistent, making it unreliable for practical protection against surveillance.
The placebo effect of wearing a tin foil hat might make individuals feel safer, even if no physical protection exists.
Relying on placebo effects for security can lead to complacency and neglect of actual protective measures.

supporting.text: Tin foil hats are not recognized by medical or scientific authorities as having any functional purpose beyond novelty or costume use.

attacks.text: Tin foil hats are not recognized by medical or scientific authorities as having any functional purpose beyond novelty or costume use.
Some conspiracy theorists claim that tin foil hats can block electromagnetic waves or mind control signals, suggesting a perceived functional purpose.
Scientific studies have debunked the effectiveness of tin foil hats in blocking electromagnetic waves, showing they may even amplify certain frequencies.
Tin foil hats are sometimes used in psychological experiments or performance art, giving them a non-novelty functional role in specific contexts.
